questions.a: Let ∅ != A ⊆ R. Suppose that A is bounded from above. Then there exists a unique s s.t. s is a least upper bound of A

questions.q: The epsilon prop of the least upper bound
questions.a: Let ∅ != A ⊆ R. Suppose that A is bounded from above and let s be an upper bound of A. Then s = sup(A) iff ∀ ε > 0 ∃ a in A s.t. a > s - ε
∀ M in R ∃ n in N s.t. n > M
∀ ε > 0 ∃ n in N s.t. 1/n < ε
Let ∅ != A ⊆ Z. Suppose that A is bounded from above. Then A has a maximal value.
R \ Q is dense in R
Let x0 and let f be a function that is defined on a deleted neighborhood of x0. Let L1, L2 and suppose that L1, L2 are two limits of f at x0. Then L1 = L2.
